utterances: Thank you, thank you.
All right.
First question, though, is this.
Yes.
And I'll bring it to you, Angela.
Yes.
An obvious one, was there a clear winner or clear loser in last night's debate?
There was no clear loser.
I think all the candidates, you know, shined as much as they could last night.
Basically, we talked a lot about the war in Iraq and terrorism, and the person who's always done well, that's always stood out, is McCain.
McCain is a shining star, and I do agree with Ron, he's the one to watch in Michigan.
and also Mitt Romney.
And I'd like to add to what Ron said, Mitt Romney's father was governor of Michigan.
And I worked for Senator Bob Dole in '95 and '96.
and Mitt Romney, to me, he looks presidential, but he can't close a sale.
And if you remember Bob Dole in 1996, he can reach the masses and I think that Mitt Romney has that Bob Dole syndrome.
So if he doesn't pull it out in Michigan, I think he's going to have a big uphill climb and a challenge.
What's your assessment, Michael?
I think all of the candidates, but for John McCain lost.
And I say that…
(Unintelligible)
…because - when McCain is on the verge of establishing himself as the clear front-runner.

I think he got a tremendous amount of boost from New Hampshire and when you look at how the other candidates really did and challenge him all very much, I think when you're the front-runner or moving toward a front-runner status, and the other candidates effectively give you a pass, then I think that just sort of confirms your strength.
And so from my perspective, McCain was the clear winner and the rest of them, really, didn't do anything to help themselves at all.

The one thing that I'd like to add is that - to your analysis -no one can take that terrorism moniker away or that patriot moniker away from McCain, and no one really wants to bash him on his policy dealing with the war on terror because he has given so much to this country, fighting in Vietnam, being a POW.
And I think that all of the candidates respect McCain.
However, don't count Giuliani out, because he's going to take Florida and then Super Tuesday is just right around the corner.
All right, let me move on to another topic.
On the Democratic side, the message so far in the campaign is all about change.
And after last night, it seems the Republicans now have their own mantra and it is Ronald Reagan.
Here's one of the many references to the popular former president that we heard last night.
This one coming from Mitt Romney.
As Ken and Henry start wrestling in the grass, Dupont tells me all about Melvin.
Well, he was different.
He was - of all the dogs I had, he was completely different.
Melvin was supposed to be a purebred Catahoula hound, Louisiana's state dog.
Turned out, Melvin was a mutt, probably part Catahoula, part Doberman.
I paid $50 for it.
But I wasn't going to return it.
And I thought a while, I'm going to put him to sleep.
Turned out to be the best dog I ever owned.

Dupont has lots of stories about what made Melvin the best, how Melvin once found his car keys in the tall grass, how they trusted Melvin so much they let him babysit their grandson all by himself in the backyard, how folks would come by just to visit with Melvin.
He'd listen.
You could talk to him, and he - sure, he understood what you were talking about.
I mean, you'd tell him anything; he'd go do it.
Most of the time, he knew what you were talking about.
He'd come sit with you.
It was weird.
(DOG BARKING)
So a couple of years ago, when Melvin was starting to show his age, the Duponts heard about a place that was cloning dogs, a lab in South Korea.
Even though it cost $100,000, the Duponts decided to do it.
So Dupont sent some of Melvin's skin cells off to the lab in South Korea.
They couldn't wait.
But the first cloned puppy they got back ended up dying right away from distemper.
So the lab tried again.
This time, they got two healthy clones.
So are they exactly alike?
Yeah.
Exactly alike.
They're the same DNA and everything.
And their personalities are the same, too.
For a while, it was like having three Melvins.
But less than two years later, Melvin's time came.
I put him down.
Was that hard for you?
Yeah, it was hard.
Do you still miss Melvin?
Quite a bit.
Does it help having these two guys here?
Oh, yeah.
You forget it real quick - real quickly.
They come running through the house and jump in your lap - 75 pound dog sitting in your lap, watching TV.
So you're back to where you're at.
There aren't a lot of cloned dogs in the world.
But the lab in South Korea that cloned Ken and Henry say they've created about 600 cloned dogs, mostly for grieving pet owners.
But not everyone thinks this is so great.
Before I went to see the Duponts, I talked with Insoo Hyun, a bioethicist at Case Western Reserve University, to find out why.
If you love dogs and you really want to have your companion animal cloned, you really do need to take very seriously the health and well-being of all the dogs that would be involved in this process.
You see, to clone a dog, you need to use a lot of other dogs, female dogs, to get eggs to make cloned dog embryos and be surrogate mother dogs.
So lots of dogs go through operations to get the eggs and impregnate the surrogate.
And most of the time, it doesn't work.
So you have to try over and over again to get each clone.
I think there are probably better ways to spend $100,000 if you really care about animals.
Hyun also wonders about the health of the cloned puppies.
Most cloned animals end up pretty sickly.
And just because the clones have the same genes as the original dogs, Hyun says that doesn't necessarily mean they're really carbon copies.
All cloning does is reproduce the genome of your original pet.
But maybe the way that your dog interacted with you and the way it looked was also strongly environmentally influenced.
And you can never obviously duplicate that kind of influence.
They want to see my squirrel trap up there (laughter).
Come on, boys.
I wonder what the Duponts think about all this.
(Whistling) Let's go.
So we head back inside.
Come on in.
So we can all sit down and talk about it.
We walk through Dr. Dupont's examining room.
He stops to point out the hunting trophies lining the walls, heads of warthogs and other critters.
Yeah, you're thirsty.
Paula fills a big bowl for the dogs.
When I press them about whether the clones are really exact duplicates, they admit there are little differences.
The white stripe on Henry's nose is a lot wider than Ken's, and he weighs a bit less.
Ken's more of a loner.
But that's about it.
They're so much like Melvin, and it's unreal.
You see Melvin every day in them.
And so far, they seem perfectly healthy.
As far as other dogs suffering, they dismiss all that.
They say they got a good look at the lab both times when they visited to pick up their clothes.
